subject: linear_algebra
title: Cross Product in R³
contentHtml:
The cross product of two vectors a and b in R³ is a vector c that satisfies the following properties:

  • a · (b × c) = 0
  • (a × b) × c = b (× denotes the cross product)

This definition might seem abstract, but it has a geometric meaning: the cross product of two vectors is perpendicular to both vectors and has a magnitude equal to the area of the parallelogram formed by the two vectors.
intuition: The cross product is a way to measure the 'orientation' of two vectors in space. It's like calculating the area of the flag created by the two vectors.
realWorldApplications: Calculating the area and volume of objects, such as finding the surface area of a 3D shape
commonMistakes: Thinking the cross product is just a scalar value
Not understanding the geometric meaning behind the formula

subject: linear_algebra
title: Cross Product in R³
contentHtml:
The cross product of two vectors a and b in R³ is a vector c that satisfies the following properties:

  • a · (b × c) = 0
  • b × (a × c) = c

This operation is geometrically meaningful, as it represents the area of the parallelogram spanned by the two input vectors.
latex: \[\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b} = (\det(A))\mathbf{n}\] where A is the matrix formed by a and b, and n is a unit vector perpendicular to both input vectors.",
name: Cross Product Formula" },
intuition: The cross product can be thought of as a way to 'orient' two vectors in space, providing information about the area they span. This property makes it useful for applications like volume and surface calculations in computer graphics and physics.
commonMistakes: Confusing the cross product with the dot product
Forgetting that the cross product is only defined in R³
